final_poem:
# The Shape of What I Knew

There was a shape my grandmother's hands could make—
not dough but the particular way she held her coffee cup,
thumb resting on the rim, white-gold ring pressing
into skin. I didn't name it then. I named it
only later, sitting in a library reading about objects
and their meanings, and there was nothing listed under *ring*
but I remembered—the way she'd tilt her head,
the window steam-fogged, the radio playing something
she wasn't listening to.

I tried to describe this to my cousin once.
Said *like a gesture only memory keeps*. He waved his hand—
a loose flourish, nothing held. And I understood:
you can't pass it back. You can point at what remains
on a plate in someone else's kitchen, the ghost
of coffee ring drying there, but that's not the thing itself.

The thing lives inside who she was.

I find myself reaching for her cup when it's empty,
running my thumb along where the handle meets the mug,
taking inventory. That particular wear,
that soft dent—after years I could tell you which hand
made it, which morning, whether rain had been in the air.

Memory doesn't store things. It stores wanting.
The wanting is what gets passed down, crisper
than any photograph, more precise than any recollection
of what was said. It's knowing how to hold
yourself in a kitchen at five, waiting
while someone pours.

I will keep doing this—reaching, running my thumb,
taking inventory. That's the smallest kind of faith I have:
that a body properly positioned can still
hear a kettle from another room,
can still turn toward it, pour, and say *here*,
meaning exactly what that word meant
the thirty-seven times I heard her use it.
